name: treatment of spent activated carbon, granular from hard coal, reactivation | activated carbon, granular | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/14815/documentation

This dataset represents the treatment of 1 kg of spent granular activated carbon (GAC) from hard coal. GAC can be reactivated through the same process with which it is produced (http://www.calgoncarbon.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Reactivation_Services_FAQ.pdf, accessed 20151209). Spent activated carbon is first heated to temperatures over 700 degrees Celsius. The activation stage, in this dataset, is achieved through vaporisation at temperatures between 800 and 1000 degrees Celsius. Activation is the key step in producing GAC. The main energy requirements are taken from "activated carbon production, granular from hard coal" dataset, in which for the burning of 3 kg of coal the requirements are: 1.6 kWh electricity and 0.33 m3 of natural gas to heat 12 kg of water. The main source of data is Bayer et al.  (2005) "Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies" and Munoz et al. (2007) Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science, 24(5): 638-651.;The result of this activity is 0.9 kg of reactivated carbon from 1 kg of spent activated carbon. To include the emissions for the carbonization, the datasets for "heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, GLO 1992" was taken as a reference to model emissions and energy requirements. The original datasets represented: "the production of heat from a 1-10 MW hard coal industrial furnace filled with 1 MJ of egg coal. The stoker-boiler furnace fires egg coals with hard coal quality between long-flame coal and fat coal. As there is no module for egg coal, the hard coal supply mix is used. The lifetime of the furnace is 20 years, which corresponds to 5000 fully load hours per year. The heating value is 28.9 MJ/kg and the efficiency factor is 80%". ;Note. The emissions from the reactivation of spent activated carbon depend on the adsorbed contaminants. This dataset does not include any contaminants but only the emissions from the reactivation process itself.

From reception of spent activated carbon.

This activity ends with the production of 0.9 kg of reactivated granular activated carbon. The datasets includes electricity consumption, the burning of natural gas for the vaporisation of water, water and the emissions from reactivation.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2029:Manufacture of other chemical products n.e.c.

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: GAC from hard coal is common practice in Central Europe (Bayer et al. 2005)
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Reref to: Bayer et al. 2005. Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies. Water research (39), 1719-1728;Refer to: Munoz et al. 2007. Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science. 5 (24), 638-651
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Partial extrapolation. Emissions for the combustion of hard coal are taken from the dataset "heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, GLO 1992". Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Based on literature data:
Bayer et al. (2005) Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbonn (GAC) adsorber refill strategies. Water research, 39: 1719-1728
Munoz et al. (2007) Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science, 24(5): 638-651.

exchanges.description: Literature value. Bayer et al. (2005) estimate 10% loss during reactivation

flow.name: activated carbon, granular
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2029:Manufacture of other chemical products n.e.c.

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Stoker-boiler furnaces emit between 300kg and 1000kg of particles per TJin if there is no particle separation. With an average of 650kg per TJin, 600kg of fly ash and 2300kg of bottom ash occurs. It is assumed that 100% of the ash is disposed (worst-case-scenario). In individual cases a 100% recycling rate is possible as well.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
EcoSpold01Location=PL

flow.name: Cadmium II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. To estimate the electricity consumption, data of the heating plant in Bern is evaluated. At full load 1.13% of the input energy is consumed as electricity. The installed capacity in auxiliary units is divided into induced draft fan (31%), primary air fan (13%), feed pump (39%), electric filter (11.8%), rust (0.8%), feeding (1.8%), slag chain (0.2%), oil supply control (0.9%) and secondary air (1.4%). It is assumed that the electricity consumption increases through part load operation. Additionally it must be considered that the observed heating plant has a capacity of about 38 MW. Therefore, it is assumed that 1.5% of the input energy is consumed as electricity.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product. Source (Fritsche et al. 1992) in the process for heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Swizterland 1992. 
To the amount required for carbonisation, a values of (1.6/3) kWh is summed to account for the energy for reactivation. This values was derived from the dataset for "activated carbon production, granular from hard coal", in which 1.6 kWh are required for 3kg of coal.
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Dry mass for spent activated carbon is 30% of wet mass (see page 644 of article below). The reference product is expressed on a dry matter basis (1kg), meaning that wet weight of spent GAC treated is 3.33(see product properties).
Munoz et al. (2007) Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science, 24(5): 638-651.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. It is assumed that 2% of the feed water is additionally required as decarbonised water (6t per TJin). For wet purification 1.5t per TJin of water is needed. Due to the lack of information the water used for cleaning can not be considered.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
Estimation. It is assumed that 2% of the feed water is additionally required as decarbonised water (6t per TJin). For wet purification 1.5t per TJin of water is needed. Due to the lack of information the water used for cleaning can not be considered. Source (Fritsche et al. 1992) in the process for heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Swizterland 1992. 
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product. To the amount required for carbonisation, 4 kg of water are added as an estimated requirement for the generation of vapour for the activation step (Bayer 2005). 4 kg were derived from the requirements for the dataset "granular activated carbon production", in which 12 kg of vapour are required for 3 kg of hard coal. This was scaled to the reference product of 1 kg. 
EcoSpold01Location=RER

Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Manganese II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Antimony ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Calculated. According to Bayer et al. (2005) 0.33m3 of natural gas are burned in order to produce 12 kg of water vapour required for activation. This activity is used as a proxy to represent this process. 4.43 kg were derived from the requirements for the dataset "granular activated carbon production", in which 13.3 MJ of heat are required to heat 12 kg of vapour. This was scaled to the 4 kg of vapour required for the reactivation of GAC.

flow.name: heat, district or industrial, natural gas

flow.name: Nitrogen oxides
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
To the evaporation amount of the input "water, completely softened, from decarbonised water, at user", the water from drying of spent GAC is added. Spent GAC has a dry mass of 30%, it is assumed that after reactivation the dry mass would be of 97% (taken from the properties set in the dataset "activated carbon production, granular from hard coal", with comment: literature value. From: <http://www.desotec.com/activated-carbon/properties/>, accessed 20151207). The water removed is calculated as in Wilhelm, Luther R., Dwayne A. Suter, and Gerald H. Brusewitz. 2004. Drying and Dehydration. Chapter 10 in Food & Process Engineering Technology, 259-284. St. Joseph, Michigan: ASAE. 
© American Society of Agricultural Engineers. (Rev. Aug. 2005.) Retrieved from https://www.asabe.org/media/184966/chapter_10_in_wilhelm_food_proc._eng._tech.pdf, accessed 19 April 2016.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Chromium III
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Stoker-boiler furnaces emit between 300kg and 1000kg of particles per TJin if there is no particle separation. With an average of 650kg per TJin, 600kg of fly ash and 2300kg of bottom ash occurs. It is assumed that 100% of the ash is disposed (worst-case-scenario). In individual cases a 100% recycling rate is possible as well.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
EcoSpold01Location=PL
